Description: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that nine children's product manufacturers, importers and sellers agreed to pay a total of more than $500,000 in civil penalties for allegedly violating the federal lead paint ban.

Nine firms agreed to pay a total of $355,000 in civil penalties to settle allegations that they knowingly failed to report to the CPSC immediately, as required by federal law, that their children's hooded sweatshirts, jackets, or sweaters were sold with drawstrings at the hood and neck and thus posed a strangulation hazard.

Company: Viking Range, LLC and Middleby Corporation
Description: Viking Range, LLC, of Greenwood, Mississippi, and its parent firm, The Middleby Corporation, agreed to pay a $4.65 million civil penalty to settle allegations that Viking failed to immediately report to CPSC that its gas ranges contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard or that the ranges created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.

A liquidating trust acting on behalf of a dissolved manufacturer of heaters agreed to pay the government a $500,000 civil penalty to settle allegations that Vornado Air Circulation Systems Inc. failed to report in a timely manner incidents of fire and overheating from defective heaters.

Company: Wagner Spray Tech Corp. and Techtronic Industries
Description: Wagner Spray Tech Corp. and Techtronic Industries Co. LTD, of Hong Kong, including its wholly-owned subsidiary Techtronic Industries North America Inc., agreed to pay an $800,000 civil penalty to resolve allegations that they failed to timely report to CPSC as required by federal law the overheating of certain defective cordless power drill battery chargers.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. agreed to pay a civil penalty of $750,000 to resolve a lawsuit filed in May 2001 by the Justice Department, on behalf of CPSC, in which the government charged the retailer with failing to report safety hazards associated with home exercise equipment.

West Bend Co., of West Bend, Wis., agreed to pay a civil penalty of $225,000 to settle allegations that the firm failed to report to CPSC in a timely manner that its water distillers presented a fire hazard.

West Bend Houswares LLC, of West Bend, Wis., agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle allegations that the company failed to report a hazard with its 10-Cup Coffeemaker Carafes and Replacement Carafes.

Company: Whalen Furniture Manufacturing Inc. dba Bayside Furnishings
Description: children's beds
sale of wooden hammock stands
sale of Pottery Barn Kids window shades

Company: Winco Fireworks Inc., Winco Fireworks International LLC and Winco Fireworks of Utah LLC
Description: Winco Fireworks Inc., Winco Fireworks International LLC and Winco Fireworks of Utah LLC, of Prairie Village, Kan., and their president agreed to pay a $600,000 civil penalty for importing and selling dangerous fireworks.
clothing-children's sweatshirts and jackets
Notes: The CPSC reduced the penalty because "the firm demonstrated an inability to pay the full amount."

Description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that Home Depot U.S.A. Inc. agreed to pay a $5.7 million civil penalty for selling and distributing previously recalled consumer products. The agreement settled allegations that the firm knowingly sold and distributed approximately 2,816 recalled products from 33 separate voluntary corrective actions during a four-year period from August 2012 through November 2016.

The CPSC announced that Polaris Industries Inc., of Medina, Minnesota, agreed to pay a $27.25 million civil penalty to settle allegations that it failed to immediately report to CPSC that models of RZR and Ranger recreational off-road vehicles contained defects that could create a substantial product hazard or that they created an unreasonable risk of serious injury or death.

Company: GROUPE SEB USA f/k/a Krups North America, Inc.
Royal Centurian Inc. and Royal Sovereign Corp.
EKO Development, Ltd., and EKO USA, LLC

Description: Cybex International agreed to pay a $7.95 million civil penalty to resolve allegations that it failed to immediately report to CPSC that its Arm Curl and Smith Press Machines contained a defect or created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.

A Chinese appliance manufacturer and two of its subsidiaries agreed to resolve criminal charges for failing to notify the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission that millions of dehumidifiers they sold to U.S. consumers were defective and could catch fire. The resolutions were the first corporate criminal enforcement actions ever brought under the Consumer Product Safety Act. Gree Electric Appliances Inc. of Zhuhai, a global appliance manufacturer headquartered in Zhuhai, China, and Hong Kong Gree Electric Appliances Sales Co. Ltd. entered into a deferred prosecution agreement in connection with a criminal information filed in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California. A criminal information filed along with the DPA charged the companies with one felony count under the CPSA of willfully failing to report consumer product safety information to the CPSC. Under the terms of the DPA, the companies agreed to a total monetary penalty of $91 million and agreed to provide restitution for any uncompensated victims of fires caused by the companies' defective dehumidifiers; $15 million paid in a previous CPSC action (see separate entry) was credited against the $91 million.
Agency: Consumer Product Safety Commission referral to the Justice Department

Description: Core Health & Fitness LLC of Vancouver, Washington, agreed to pay a $6.5 million civil penalty to resolve CPSC charges that it failed to immediately report to the agency, as required by law, that its Cable Cross Over Machines and Dual Adjustable Pulley Machines contained a defect or created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.

Clawfoot Supply agreed to pay a $6 millioncivil penalty to resolve allegations that it failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that its Wall-Mounted Teak Folding Shower Seats contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard and created an unreasonable risk of serious injury to consumers.

The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that Segway Powersports Inc. was assessed a $5 millioncivil penalty to resolve allegatgions that it knowingly imported ATVs without a CPSC-approved ATV action plan in violation of the Consumer Product Safety Act. CPSC agreed to suspend all but $1.25 million of the $5 million penalty based on Segway's sworn representations that paying a penalty exceeding that amount would cause the company financial hardship and compel it to cease business operations.
The TJX Companies Inc. agreed to pay a $13 millioncivil penaltyfor selling, offering for sale, and distributing previously recalled consumer products.

Vornado Air LLC agreed to pay a $7.5 millioncivil penalty to resolve CPSC's allegations that it failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that its VH101 Personal Vortex electric space heater contained a defect or created an unreasonable risk of serious injury.

Peloton Interactive Inc. agreed to pay a $19,065,000civil penalty to resolve CPSC's charges that it knowingly failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that its Tread+ treadmill contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard and created an unreasonable risk of serious injury to consumers. The civil penalty also settled charges that Peloton knowingly distributed recalled treadmills in violation of the Consumer Product Safety Act.

Gree USA, Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of a Chinese appliance company, was sentenced to pay a $500,000 criminal fine after pleading guilty to failing to notify the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission that millions of dehumidifiers it sold to U.S. consumers were defective and could catch fire.
Agency: Consumer Product Safety Commission referral to the Justice Department

Description: Generac Power Systems, Inc., of Waukesha, Wisconsin, agreed to pay a $15,800,000civil penalty to resolve CPSC charges that it failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that 32 models of its Generac and DR 6500 Watt and 8000 Watt portable generators contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard and created an unreasonable risk of serious injury to consumers.
Agency: Consumer Product Safety Commission referral to the Justice Department

Description: Whirlpool Corp. agreed to pay an $11,500,000civil penalty to resolve charges that it knowingly failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that 17 models of its JennAir, KitchenAid, and Whirlpool brand electric radiant heat cooktops contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard and created an unreasonable risk of serious injury to consumers.

BJ's Wholesale Club, Inc. agreed to pay a $9 millioncivil penalty to resolve CPSC's charges that it knowingly failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that portable air conditioners manufactured by Royal Sovereign International, Inc. and sold by BJ's contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard and created an unreasonable risk of serious injury or death to consumers.

HSN Inc., of St. Petersburg, Florida, agreed to pay a $16 millioncivil penalty to resolve CPSC's charges that HSN knowingly failed to immediately report to CPSC, as required by law, that its Joy Mangano-brand My Little Steamer and My Little Steamer Go Mini contained a defect that could create a substantial product hazard or created an unreasonable risk of serious injury to consumers.
